data.title: Cuckoo revisited, Cage rejuvenated and the return of the Mini
data.meta_description: The inside story of a Seventies classic edges out Ridley Scott's slick, entertaining comedy and a neatly reworked Italian Job.
data.text:
Completely Cuckoo

(87 mins, nc) Directed by Charles Kiselyak

The Italian Job

(110 mins, 12A) Directed by F. Gary Gray; starring Mark Wahlberg, Charlize Theron, Edward Norton, Donald Sutherland

Matchstick Men

(116, 12A) Directed by Ridley Scott; starring Nicolas Cage, Sam Rockwell, Alison Lohman

White Oleander

(109 mins, 12A) Directed by Peter Kosminsky; starring Michelle Pfeiffer, Alison Lohman, Renée Zellweger

Underworld

(121 mins, 15) Directed by Len Wiseman; starring Kate Beckinsale, Scott Speedman, Bill Nighy

Raising Victor Vargas

(88 mins, 15) Directed by Peter Sollett; starring Victor Rasuk, Judy Marte

Nine Dead Gay Guys

(83 mins, 18) Directed by Lab Ky Mo; starring Glen Mulhern, Brendan Mackey, Steven Berkoff

The Spirit of the Beehive

(97 mins, PG) Directed by Victor Erice; starring Ana Torrent

The most valuable new film this week (it actually dates from 1988) is Completely Cuckoo, a fascinating account by Charles Kiselyak, a specialist in documentaries about the movie-making process, of the making of One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.

Kirk Douglas, who owned the rights to Ken Kesey's novel and appeared in a Broadway production in 1961, offered the film to Milos Forman in Prague in 1963. But Czech customs seized the script, and Forman didn't see it for a decade until Michael Douglas, who had taken over the production from his father, sent it to him in his American exile. He thought it exactly like the communist country from which he had fled in 1968.

Jack Nicholson was only offered the role of the anarchic McMurphy after Gene Hackman and Marlon Brando had turned it down, and the rest of the cast, who lived with and studied real patients, were unknowns, though they're now famous.

Possibly the most interesting aspect of the picture is the warm co-operation that the moviemakers got from the enlightened staff and inmates of the psychiatric hospital in Oregon where it was shot. Apparently the hospital, by the time Kiselyak came to make this documentary, had become a far more repressive place than it had been in the mid-1970s.

The Italian Job is a very loose remake of the slack, xenophobic 1969 British comedy thriller, a few incidents and names from which it retains. The original became a cult movie largely because of a single Michael Caine line ('You're only supposed to blow the bloody doors off'), the three super-charged Mini Coopers carrying the stolen bullion in Turin, Noël Coward's final, very camp screen appearance, and a song now popular among boozy football fans.

Gary Gray's version is tauter, better made but insufficiently idiosyncratic to attract a cult following. It begins with a successful $35m bullion robbery in Venice, after which one of the crooks (Edward Norton) makes off with the loot after killing the gang's aged leader (Donald Sutherland). It ends with the vengeful survivors led by Mark Wahlberg staging another raid (involving Mini Coopers on Hollywood Boulevard and in the Los Angeles underground) to punish Norton and repossess the bullion. Now that justice rather than greed is the motive, they become honourable heroes. There's a brief homage to Caine when Norton watches Alfie on TV.

Equally slick and sleek, and also involving a car chase in Los Angeles, is Ridley Scott's comedy thriller Matchstick Men, which has nothing to do with L.S. Lowry, although on an eclectic soundtrack that features numbers by Bobby Darin, Frank Sinatra, Mantovani, Herb Alpert and Marvin Gaye, there's 'Leaning on a Lamp Post' sung by another Lancashire icon, George Formby. A 'matchstick man' in this context is a confidence trickster, though the film's ace grifter (Nicolas Cage) prefers the term 'con artist'.

He's a twitchy compulsive-obsessive, falling apart probably through guilt induced by his exploitative activities. To ease his pain, a shrink advises him to contact the 14-year-old daughter (Alison Lohman), born to his ex-wife after their marriage broke up. Like the little girl who may or may not be the con man's offspring in Bogdanovich's Paper Moon, Cage's spirited daughter breaks through his defence systems and learns her father's trade. It's an entertaining divertissement which Scott must have had fun making after the heavy duty of Gladiator, Hannibal and Black Hawk Down. I'll say no more about the plot, except that serious students of con movies might well rise to the challenge of guessing the outcome.

Alison Lohman got her role in the mainstream Matchstick Men as a result of an impressive big-screen debut in the independent movie White Oleander, the first feature film by the British documentarist, Peter Kosminsky.

Lohman plays Astrid Magnussen, a 14-year-old who goes through a succession of foster parents and orphanages after her mother (Michelle Pfeiffer) is jailed for the murder of her unfaithful lover (Billy Connolly). The mother, a pretentious photographer obsessed with the notion of the artist's superiority to ordinary folk, poisons all her daughter's relationships, driving one of the foster mothers to suicide. Eventually, of course, Astrid establishes her independence as a woman and as a portrait artist.

The mother is an egotistical monster, all the men (except for a sympathetic fellow orphanage inmate) are desperately weak, and the varied foster mothers (blue-collar religious maniac, neglected affluent Malibu housewife, hippie street-trader) are too much of a cross-section of southern California to ring true. The film ends on an unconvincingly affirmative note, but by sharp editing and the use of a hand-held camera Kosminksy keeps the picture moving at immense speed.

Directed by Len Wiseman, a specialist in commercials and music videos, Underworld is a commonplace horror movie set in present-day Budapest where aristocratic vampires living in a luxurious gothic pile continue their centuries old battle with werewolves, who live in sewers and tunnels beneath the city.

It's hi-tech warfare with the lycanthropes using liquid daylight in their bullets and the vampires filling their ammunition with silver nitrate. The violence is relentless, the pace unvaried, the dialogue laughable. The music resembles Ravel's 'Bolero' played at double speed on a pneumatic drill. Bill Nighy, however, brings a world-weary gravitas to the vampires' immortal leader, and Kate Beckinsale's vampire warrior looks rather fetching in a figure-hugging black Latex suit and what in Diana Rigg's Avengers period were known as kinky boots. The desaturated colour photography is by the gifted British cameraman Tony Pierce-Roberts who shot A Room With a View, Howards End, The Remains of the Day and The Golden Bowl for Merchant-Ivory.

Raising Victor Vargas, the promising, shoestring debut of a young New Yorker, Peter Sollett, concerns a macho Hispanic teenager meeting his match and becoming a real man when he starts courting a beauty who has been hardened by fighting off the advances of cocky young men. The setting is a hot summer in the Latino housing projects of Manhattan's Lower East Side and the entirely non-professional cast give the film a real authority.

The first movie of a Chinese Irishman, Lab Ky Mo's low-budget comedy Nine Dead Gay Guys is an appalling comedy set in London's gay underworld. Trading in homosexual stereotypes, it tells the story of two boozy young Irish rentboys who when not talking about blowjobs are giving them. There is unlikely to be anything less amusing or more offensive this year. Some misguidedly generous impulse led Steven Berkoff to be associated with it.

The Spanish filmmaker Victor Erice, now aged 63 and having a retrospective at the NFT, has directed two fiction films and a documentary. But like Jean Vigo, who died at the age of 29 and also made two features and a documentary, he has done enough to earn a seat in the cinematic pantheon. Erice's first film, The Spirit of the Beehive, is his masterpiece. Made in 1973 when Spain was preparing to emerge from the long dark night of Franco's rule, it's set in 1940 in a remote corner of a country left emotionally numb by the civil war. This beautiful, austere movie has a miraculous performance from Ana Torrent as a child obsessed with the figure of Boris Karloff's monster in the 1931 Frankenstein.

Philip French's top five films

1. Crimson Gold (12A)

Banned in Iran, this film about a botched heist in Tehran throws vivid light on a deeply unjust society.

2. Belleville Rendez-vous (12A)

Wonderfully dotty French animated comedy involving the Tour de France and the Mafia Top 5.

3. Spirited Away (PG)

A wilful 10-year-old girl has a transforming dream in this delightful Japanese animated ghost story.

4. Good Bye Lenin! (15)

Thoughtful post-Cold War comedy offering an alternative history of Germany since 1989.
